title: 115_s3167
content: The Act may be cited as the "9/11 Memorial Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The "9/11 Memorial Act" defines key terms such as "covered memorial" as a memorial in the US honoring 9/11 victims, "eligible entity" as an organization focused on memorial operations and preservation, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. The "9/11 Memorial Act" defines terms like "covered memorial" as a US memorial honoring 9/11 victims, "eligible entity" as an organization focused on memorial operations, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. Competitive grants are available for covered memorials. The Secretary will award competitive grants to eligible entities for the operation, security, and maintenance of covered memorials. Grants must be used for these purposes and will be awarded within 60 days of application review. Grant funds will remain available until expended, and selection criteria prioritize eligible entities. The selection criteria for eligible entities receiving grants for covered memorials prioritize the needs, ability, and commitment to ensuring visitor security, matching grant amounts with non-Federal assets, benefiting the greatest number of visitors, and using funds for preservation and education. The grant criteria prioritize eligible entities that prioritize visitor security, match grant amounts with non-Federal assets, benefit a large number of visitors, and use funds for preservation and education. Grants are limited to memorials that offer free admission to military members, first responders, and 9/11 victims' families, as well as dedicated free admission hours for the general public. The eligible entity receiving the grant must provide financial statements for review by the Secretary and the public. Reports detailing grant funds usage must be submitted annually to the Secretary and Congress. The Secretary may require additional information for grant program administration. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2019 through 2023.
